data.title: 8 Magnificent Museums In Manchester For A Much-Needed Dose Of Culture
data.meta_description: Next time you need a little cultural reset, head to these spectacular museums in Manchester uncovering the city's heritage.
data.text:
While Manchester is commonly associated with its thriving food and drink scene, the city is also home to a number of fantastic museums â€“ perfect for pottering around next time itâ€™s raining or you fancy a little bit of a cultural reset. From museums uncovering the cityâ€™s industrial heritage, to those telling the heartfelt stories of people from the past, hereâ€™s our guide to the best museums in Manchester.

1. Imperial War Museum North

Manchester is home to the Northâ€™s first Imperial War Museum â€“ where Mancs can see memorabilia from conflicts since the First World War, while exploring the effects these conflicts have had on the world. Sitting on the Manchester Ship Canal, the museum boasts impressive architecture and interiors, which are designed to unsettle and disorientate you with sloping walls and sharp angles. Discover art, photographs, artefacts and impressive exhibitions â€“ which includes the beautiful poppy installation.

ğŸ“ Imperial War Museum North, Trafford Wharf Rd, Trafford Park, Stretford, M17 1TZ.

ğŸŸï¸ Entrance is free and you can get tickets here.

ğŸ•’ The museum is open daily from 10am-5pm.

2. National Football Museum

Englandâ€™s national museum of football can be found right here in Manchester â€“ boasting tons of football memorabilia from over the years. Fun fact: my own dadâ€™s fanzine lives in this very museum. Fans can explore 140,000 boots, balls, programmes, paintings, postcards and ceramics â€“ each curated to tell the story of the beautiful game.

ğŸ“ National Football Museum, Urbis Building Cathedral Gardens, Todd St, M4 3BG.

ğŸŸï¸ Tickets can be booked here.

ğŸ•’ The museum is open daily from 10am-5pm, with last admission at 4pm.

3. Science and Industry Museum

The Science and Industry Museum is one of the most perfect museums for family days out in Manchester â€“ taking guests on a trip to the Industrial Revolution and beyond. A period of time synonymous with Manchesterâ€™s history, the museum explores the â€˜ideas that change the worldâ€™, showcasing cars and other inventions, Manchesterâ€™s cotton history and so much more.

ğŸ“ Science and Industry Museum, Liverpool Rd, M3 4FP.

ğŸŸï¸ Tickets are free and you can book here.

ğŸ•’ The museum is open daily from 10am-5pm.

4. Museum of Transport, Greater Manchester

Got a thing for vintage vehicles? Youâ€™ll find plenty of them at the Museum of Transport. Telling the story of Manchesterâ€™s transport history, guests can explore retro buses from the 1930â€™s onwards, trams from the early 1900s, vintage signs, furniture and so much more â€“ all in one place.

ğŸ“ Museum of Transport, Boyle St, Cheetham Hill, M8 8UW.

ğŸŸï¸ Find out more about admission here..

ğŸ•’ The museum is open Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 10am-4.30pm.

5. Peopleâ€™s History Museum

Uncovering the story of the people of Britain, the Peopleâ€™s History Museum explore democracy throughout the years, from the heartfelt stories of refugees and asylum seekers, to the history of Labour and numerous trade unions. Learn more about figures such as Manchesterâ€™s very own Emmeline Pankhurst and other revolutionaries, while learning more about the moments in history that have brought us to where we are today.

ğŸ“ Peopleâ€™s History Museum, Left Bank, M3 3ER.

ğŸŸï¸ Entry is free and you can book a slot here.

ğŸ•’ The museum is open from 10am-5pm every day, except Tuesdays.

6. Manchester Jewish Museum

Manchester Jewish Museum is one of most unique museums in the city as it resides in a former synagogue. The museum honours the cityâ€™s Jewish community â€“ not only keeping the beautiful synagogue in prime condition, but showcasing tens of thousands of historic items, too. The building is considered â€œone of the highlights of Victorian Gothic architecture in the countryâ€, and you can see it for yourself seven days a week.

ğŸ“ Manchester Jewish Museum, 190 Cheetham Hill Rd, Cheetham Hill, M8 8LW.

ğŸŸï¸ Find out about admission here.

ğŸ•’ The museum is open daily from 10am-5pm, with final admission at 4pm.

7. Manchester Museum

Back after a big renovation, Manchester Museum reopened in February 2023 and features the Museumâ€™s historic collections as well as new displays. Visitors can see works collected by the University of Manchester, the museum boasts stunning art created by the South Asian diaspora communities in the UK, alongside a space devoted to Chinese culture and so much more. Thereâ€™s also a massive dinosaur display that you simply canâ€™t miss!

ğŸ“ Manchester Museum, University of Manchester, Oxford Rd, M13 9PL.

ğŸŸï¸ Admission is free however pre-booking tickets is recommended to guarantee entry to events and exhibitions, which you can book here.

ğŸ•’ The museum is open Tuesdays-Fridays 10am-5pm, Saturdays 8am-5pm and Sundays 10am-5pm.

8. Hat Works Museum

Found inside one of Stockportâ€™s most recognisable buildings (you know, given that it has â€˜Hat Museumâ€™ emblazoned on its huge chimney), Stockportâ€™s Hat Museum is the first of its kind in the UK â€“ putting a spotlight on the countryâ€™s formerly lavish hatting industry. There you can see the stunning Victorian mill, which now houses tons of millinery equipment once used to create the countryâ€™s hats. Thereâ€™s a huge collection of vintage hats to discover, too, shedding light on fashions throughout the years. Hat Works Museum will re-open for general admission on March 14, 2024 following four years of closure for refurbishment and reinterpretation.

ğŸ“ Hat Works Museum, Wellington Road South, Stockport, SK3 0EU.

ğŸŸï¸ Admission is free and you can book your visit here.

ğŸ•’ The museum is open Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 10am to 4pm. Last admission at 3:15pm.
